newsitem.title: USA: White House blasts Republicans on disaster bill.
newsitem.headline: White House blasts Republicans on disaster bill.

text.p: The White House Friday charged that the Republican Congress has left disaster victims in 33 states "short-changed" by failing to enact emergency aid.

"Communities that have been depending on this funding to get back on their feet are being left short-changed by a short-sighted Congress, which does not reflect well on the Republican leaders of Congress," White House Press Secretary Mike McCurry said.
President Clinton "is extremely disappointed that those citizens of 33 states that need access to disaster assistance ... will see some of their assistance jeopardized," McCurry said.
House Republican leaders Thursday allowed members to take a week's break after blocking efforts to provide disaster aid for the flooded Midwest.
Both parties support disaster aid, but Clinton has threatened to veto the $8.4 billion emergency spending bill because of unrelated spending and environmental amendments added by Republicans.
"Let's pray there's no hurricane any time soon," McCurry told reporters, saying "there's no money left" to deal will many of the problems facing disaster victims.
